Rise to Power. Some Jews, like the rabbis of the Tannaim and Amoraim, believed that the Messiah, the longed-for liberator, would be ‘cleansed’ before the end of the age. Their idea, called Seder Hishtalshelut (‘the order of redemption’), envisaged a gradual revelation of the Torah over seven hundred centuries, culminating in the era of messianic peace.
In the Roman period, during which Christianity was still relatively unknown, this theory found resonance among the Galileans and Samaritans, who feared becoming marginalized in a redemptive age dominated by the Pharisees from Palestine. When Constantine acclaimed Christianity as the official religion, Galilean Jews could no longer pretend that the rabbinic interpretation had a future, and some of them took up the Christian interpretation, embracing it both politically (or ‘religiously’) as well as philosophically as the ‘highest’ teaching.
On an even deeper level, they recognized that Christianity’s view of the Messiah was, in essence, the same as their own – both were meant to arise out of despondency, in time to achieve total justice and total freedom.
In Judaism for centuries, the image of Jesus was of a ‘fallen’ figure, who failed, or pretended to fail, or was rejected as a messiah in order to save posterity from his dangerous teachings. The Haggadah tells how Jacob, fearing his son Joseph’s dreams of greatness, gave him a coat, but sent a snake as a contrast, so that he would know who would reign supreme.
Now it might seem that, if Jews had the Messiah coming from Christianity, they needed not feel threatened or anxious. This was not so, as some, like Hillel, had, along with Jesus, interpreted the Torah radically. The Torah, they taught, was not a ‘law’, still less the ultimate wisdom, but a springboard for deeper thought, as well as openness and sympathy for others – as long as the latter did not impede Jewish uniqueness.
In the Jerusalem Talmud (8th century), Hillel’s teaching went further, arguing that he and Jesus were one. Jesus, according to him, was merely another ‘Kabbalist’, one of those who in their search for the divine, went beyond the letter of the law, or else interpreted it differently.
For some, this meant that, from a Christian perspective, Jesus was not a failed Christian, but another great Jewish sage, who offered alternative interpretations.
This was a radical message, as in a Christian view, he had failed in his main mission as Messiah. But at the same time, it represented a recognition that, while different in some ways, there was commonality at the heart of the Judaism/Christianity divide.
Historical Reasons: It has long been argued that, in fact, Jesus, with his new interpretation of the Torah, was not seen by his contemporaries as the Messiah promised in Scripture. Christianity as a movement – and at one stage a religious sect – seems to have needed Jesus to provide a rationale for his faith. Moreover, it may not be coincidental that the earliest Church writings take the form of ‘defences’ and ‘apologist treatises’ – an acknowledgement of their ‘alienness’, an effort to claim its legitimacy.
In this framework, Jesus, while an outsider, may not have been as much of an outsider, in terms of Christianity, as some scholars had thought. The Talmud may not reflect the truth of the matter. However, in order to argue their case, Christians had to come up with reasons why Jesus should be preferred as the messiah, even over other Jewish leaders considered more canonical by Christianity – the Maccabees, the Hasmoneans, Pharisees and even Hillel – whose ideas and names are familiar to Jews, but not to Christians. This effort may have led them to the position that Jesus was the Messiah, which they saw as necessary to solve the theological ‘problem’ of a God who could not save his own people.
This explanation, however, raises further questions. Where is the evidence that, in the Christian early Church, Jews actually favored Hillel more than they did Jesus, as the Messiah? If Hillel was even considered as such, why was it that he needed to be ‘defended’ against his detractors, whereas Jesus could claim messiahship easily?
Convergence on Exodus 27 and 30. With regard to the latter question, I can trace the convergence on this verse by both Christians and Jews to the first half of the 4th century c.e.
Historically, Christians did not, at the time of early Christianity in the 1st century c.e. and even in the first few centuries of Christianity, emphasize any one particular theme in their worship. The early Church, like Judaism before it, was an open and pluralistic community – far from a unitary denomination in a monolithic hierarchy.
When, in the 3rd century, there became a desire for a more uniform and regulated set of beliefs, Christians began referring to themselves as ‘Christians’ – a name they had avoided preferring to themselves as ‘the church of Christ’.
In this context, the name itself indicated that this church was Christian only in name. The New Testament writings at this time were not yet canonized, so their meaning was disputed. There were too many groups with differing beliefs: Pharisees (also called Hillelites), Sadducees, the Jewish sect of the Essenes. One notable example was Simon Judeo, a ‘Christian’ of the 2nd century c.e., who rejected Christ’s cross and believed it to be ‘the world’s’.
As in Judaism, this diversity also prevailed in early Christianity. Some had the ‘traditional’ Jesus: a failed messiah, executed by the Romans in the first century, who was a Jewish sage and teacher but not a miracle worker – though he did heal and prophesy about the future. His followers believed he was resurrected, and that salvation lay in Christ’s imminent Second Coming. Others, like Ebionites, only accepted him as a Jewish sage. Some accepted Paul, one of Jesus’ most energetic disciples, as ‘the true disciple’ of Jesus – though, unlike Jesus, he was seen as having died on the cross of persecution.
Dividing the Christ: Around 300 c.e., in Rome, the Gnostic, Valentinus, proposed a major division of Christ: a heavenly, spiritual Christ, whose role in salvation lay in helping the human soul rise above the material, or ‘demiurgy’ world. It was Valentinus who proposed the idea of the Second Coming – Jesus would appear as the spiritual Messiah or ‘Son of Man’, descend from the heavens on a chariot of light, in order to deliver the human race from its bonds. This idea did not originate with Valentinus, but with Jesus himself, and has been a central one for many Christians.
But for Valentinus, the focus was on the salvation of the spirit from its entanglement in the world of demiurgy. Here, there would be no resurrection of the body, but only a spiritual, immortal salvation.
In this perspective, Jesus and Paul, as human beings and not divine, were seen as servants of God – useful in helping souls reach the ideal state, but subordinate to the supreme and divine Spirit. This, in a sense, represented a continuity with the earlier Jewish understanding of the Messiah, both in terms of eschatology, as well as divine as well as historical priority – Jesus had failed, perhaps deliberately, and so, it was argued, the spiritual ‘Son of Man’ would triumph. So while the focus of salvation lay in Jesus’s life, and his role on earth, the ‘superior’ part of salvation, in the spiritual world, was ‘Jesus’ – the ‘son of God’, also known as the ‘Son of Man’.
The ‘Second Coming’: Valentinus and his followers also believed in the imminent Second Coming of the ‘Son of Man’. This was a time when the spirit would rule, and the material world would be destroyed. It was a return of the fullness of powers, much like God’s resting from the labors of Creation. Here, there would be no resurrection and no bodily life – the two main components of traditional Christian belief.

othing:

- Avoid heavy or tight clothing that can trap heat and cause overheating.
- Wear wide-brimmed hats that protect your face and neck from direct sunlight.

Water Safety:
- Familiarize yourself with basic water safety rules and be aware of potential hazards.
- Swim at designated swimming areas and never swim alone.
- Always wear a life jacket when participating in water activities, especially if you’re not a strong swimmer.
- Use a buddy system and inform others of your swimming location.
- Be mindful of weather conditions, water currents, and lifeguard restrictions.
Staying Safe While Participating in Extreme Heat Activities:
- Avoid strenuous outdoor activities during the hottest part of the day (usually 10 am to 4 pm).
- Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water throughout the day, not just when you feel thirsty.
- Plan activities during cooler times of the day, such as early morning or late afternoon.
- Listen to your body and take frequent breaks in shaded or air-conditioned areas.
- Know the signs of heat exhaustion or heat stroke and seek immediate medical attention if symptoms persist.
The summer is an exciting time to enjoy outdoor activities and create lasting memories with friends and family. By prioritizing safety, considering age-appropriate options, staying hydrated, using sun protection, and being aware of potential hazards, you can have a fantastic and safe adventure during the summer months. Remember, being prepared is half the battle, so enjoy your time outdoors responsibly!
How to Plan a Safe Summer Camping Trip with Children
Summer is the perfect time for families to take a break from the daily routine and spend time in nature. Camping trips offer a unique opportunity to bond, explore, and create lasting memories with loved ones. However, ensuring the safety of children during a camping trip requires careful planning and preparation. Here are some tips to help you plan a safe and memorable summer camping adventure:
- Choose Suitable Camping Locations and Equipment:
- Select a campsite that offers family-friendly amenities, such as designated play areas and restrooms.
- Invest in high-quality camping gear, including a sturdy tent, sleeping bags, mosquito repellent, and first aid supplies.
- Ensure children have suitable clothing and footwear for different weather conditions.
- Pack essential items like a portable charger, a waterproof bag for valuables, a camping stove, and cooking utensils.
- Prepare for Emergencies:
- Review the location’s emergency protocol and familiarize yourself with the nearest emergency services.
- Carry a well-stocked first aid kit with medications, bandages, adhesive tape, and tweezers.
- Teach your children basic first aid skills, such as treating minor cuts, applying bandages, and recognizing signs of heatstroke or dehydration.
- Safety Around Wildlife:
- Research local wildlife and educate your children about staying safe around animals.
- Keep food and drinks in secure containers to avoid attracting animals.
- Store food properly using bear-proof containers or hanging food out of reach.
- Never feed wildlife, and maintain a safe distance from them.
- Keep Away from Water Safety Hazards:
- If camping near bodies of water like lakes, rivers, or ocean beaches, follow strict safety guidelines.
- Teach children about water safety, such as never swimming alone, staying within designated swimming areas, and wearing a life jacket.
- Ensure children understand the importance of not diving into shallow waters or standing in strong currents.
- Maintain a Buddy System:
- Always stick together and use the buddy system, especially with older children.
- Assign adults to supervise pairs of children, ensuring one person is always accountable for keeping an eye on their designated buddy.
- Set clear rules for responsible behavior, such as no running near campsite boundaries, following campfire safety instructions, and not releasing balloons into the air.
- Consider Children’s Abilities:
- Choose age-appropriate activities and trails that align with each child’s interests and physical abilities.
- Check the distance and difficulty level of hiking trails beforehand.
- Set reasonable expectations and encourage breaks when needed.
- Never push children beyond their limits and monitor their comfort levels during physical activities like fishing, kayaking, or biking.
- Plan Indoor Activities:
- Have a backup plan for rainy days, such as board games, card games, or family storytelling sessions.
- Keep a selection of indoor activities that can engage children and provide distractions during unfavorable weather.
- Ensure that indoor activities are accessible, safe, and within comfortable temperature ranges.
- Be Mindful of the Environment:
- Respect the natural environment and practice leave-no-trace principles.
- Teach children the importance of not disturbing animals, removing sticks or stones, and cleaning up after themselves.
- Set limits on noise levels and discuss the impact of loud voices and excessive noise on wildlife and other campers’ enjoyment.
- Emphasize the value of preserving the beauty of nature for future generations.
By prioritizing safety, considering age-appropriate options, preparing for emergencies, and being mindful of the environment, you can create a fun and secure summer camping experience for your family. Follow these tips closely to ensure that your summer camping trip becomes an unforgettable adventure in nature for everyone involved!
Summer Water Safety Tips for Children
Water is a wonderful and refreshing element, especially during the summer months. However, water can also pose potential risks if not approached with caution. To ensure the safety of children around water this summer, follow these essential tips:
- Lifeguard Presence:
- Whenever possible, choose swimming spots that have lifeguards on duty.
- If lifeguards are present, adhere to their instructions and never leave children unattended near the water.
- Keep Children Within Arm’s Reach:
- Always maintain visual contact with children within a few feet of open water.
- Avoid engaging in activities that may distract your attention, such as conversing with other family members or using smartphones.
- Utilize Flotation Devices:
- Ensure children wear safety vests or floaties when near the water.
- Regularly check the flotation devices for any damage or malfunction.
- Consider a US Coast Guard-approved personal flotation device (PFD).
- Teach Young Swimmers About Water Awareness:
- Initiate water safety lessons early on, especially for children still learning to swim.
- Demonstrate how to float on one’s back and emphasize the importance of facing forward with arms at the sides.
- Encourage children to seek assistance from lifeguards in case of difficulties.
- Enroll Children in Age-Appropriate Lessons:
- Utilize local swim schools or water safety lessons to provide formal swimming instruction for children before getting them in deep water.
- Consider enrolling younger kids in programs that offer water readiness lessons (WARL) to help them familiarize themselves with water concepts and basic skills.
- Foster Boating Safety:
- If you plan to engage in boating, familiarize yourself with age-appropriate boat safety guidelines.
- Ensure that children wear life jackets at all times on board a boat.
- Provide instruction on boat safety basics, including navigation rules, docking procedures, and basic water rescue techniques.
- Maintain Regular Breaks:
- Take regular breaks from water activities, both in and out of the swimming pool.
- Find cool, shaded areas, or indoor locations with air conditioning to let children rest and stay hydrated.
- Encourage children to engage in water-related activities that limit their exposure to extreme heat, like playing in sprinklers or water balloon fights.
- Equipment Check:
- Regularly inspect any inflatable toys (like water wings or tubes) for sharp edges and holes before allowing children to use them.
- Monitor all pool, spa, or water-based equipment for any potential hazards such as frayed ropes, broken slides, or slippery surfaces.
- Report and address safety concerns promptly.
- Educate Children on Pool and Water Safety Stations:
- Show children how to recognize and use pool or water safety stations, such as lifelines, safety rings, or handg

brought on by the pandemic caused by SARS-CoV2.
The global roll out of emergency vaccines to protect people from COVID-19 has been unprecedented. However, the vaccination of at-risk individuals and high risk groups, specifically the elderly, those who are immunocompromised and those with long COVID, who are most susceptible to the deadly health effects of SARS-CoV2, is still a challenge in developing countries such as South Africa.
“COVID-19 vaccination rates are lagging in many parts of the world, including South Africa and low-middle income countries, where vulnerable people are at the greatest risk of death from the virus,” explained Prof Marisa Venter, senior author of the study and the Chair of Microbiology Division at UCT.
In South Africa, the roll out of vaccination is significantly lower than other nations, with only 7% of South Africans vaccinated as of May. Although there is an increase in availability of vaccines, vaccine hesitancy poses a significant problem.
“In recent months, vaccine hesitancy and lower overall awareness of the need to get vaccinated has stunted the uptake of vaccination in many countries, including South Africa,” added Venter.
Long COVID symptoms
COVID-19 is not over once people are treated. In approximately 30% of COVID-19 patients, they are not out of danger. Instead, they experience a range of COVID-19-related long-term symptoms, commonly called long COVID or post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC).
These symptoms may appear days to weeks after the initial recovery from acute COVID-19, when a patient was unwell enough to seek medical help. Long COVID might cause some patients to suffer from fever, cough, difficulty breathing, headache and memory problems. While most patients have moderate to mild symptoms, others can suffer from a debilitating illness that might severely affect their quality of life.
COPD to CTS
The researchers from UCT and the University of Edinburgh set out to examine the effectiveness of COVID-19 and flu vaccines in patients suffering from Long COVID.
While some patients suffering from long COVID have a reduced immune response following vaccination, other patients might not experience any change in their long COVID symptoms at all following vaccination.
According to Venter, there is no straightforward way to predict which patients are most susceptible to this outcome. “This might be due to patients having immunodeficiency due to the disease itself or a state of poor immune health such as malnutrition, co-morbid diseases, HIV infection, cancer, or cancer treatment. It might also be that some patients with long COVID have a partial loss of long-term memory related to their vaccination.”
Co-author of the study Prof Michelle Acheson, Associate Dean (International) and Director of Global Health Research, Institute for Infection, Immunity and Inflammation at the University of Edinburgh, and Director of World Allergy Society’s (WAS) South African Network added, “While the reasons why vaccination may not result in improved outcomes for some patients remain unclear, a key message for our clinical colleagues is not to rule out vaccinating patients with Long COVID given that there is no negative effect from vaccination.”
Venter said, “These findings may inform future practice and help improve vaccine strategies to ensure that patients with Long COVID receive the care they need to reduce the burden of COVID-19.”
Immunisation is no longer limited to the 15- to 18-year-old children; this means that adults need to look after themselves as well.

Exercise:

1. The study suggests that vaccination has a negative effect on Long COVID patients.

    Entail, Contradict, Neutral

2. The reason why some Long COVID patients don't seem to improve after vaccination remains completely understood and identified clearly.

    Entail, Contradict, Neutral

3. Vaccination for Long COVID patients is discouraged according to the key findings of the study.

    Entail, Contradict, Neutral

4. People suffering from Long COVID might exhibit temporary immune memory loss post-vaccination.

    Entail, Contradict, Neutral

5. Every individual with Long COVID will experience severe impact on their quality of life regardless of vaccination status.

    Entail, Contradict, Neutral

6. Vaccination strategies for patients with Long COVID are not being informed by current research findings, potentially neglecting these individuals’ care.

    Entail, Contradict, Neutral

7. The research findings unequivocally establish why some patients with Long COVID lose immune response post-vaccination.

    Entail, Contradict, Neutral

Solutions:

1. **Contradict** - The paragraph states that there is no negative effect from vaccination on Long COVID patients, contradicting the notion that vaccination has a negative effect.

2. **Neutral** - The paragraph explains that researchers do not know why some Long COVID patients don't improve post-vaccination, and hence neither "entails" nor "contradicts" that the reasons are completely understood and identified.

3. **Contradict** - According to the paragraph, key findings should not discourage vaccination in Long COVID patients, which contrasts with the statement.

4. **Neutral** - While the paragraph mentions patients with Long COVID may have a partial long-term memory related to vaccination, it does not state that this memory loss is temporary, making this statement neutral with respect to the paragraph content.

5. **Neutral** - The paragraph notes that a large percentage of Long COVID patients suffer moderate to mild symptoms, but it does not universally say that every individual experiences a severe impact on their quality of life.

6. **Contradict** - The paragraph suggests that these findings may inform future practices, implying that current vaccination strategies are indeed informed by them, contradicting the statement.

7. **Contradict** - The paragraph clearly states that it remains unclear why some Long COVID patients might not have an improved immune response post-vaccination. Hence, this statement contradicts the paragraph which does not establish a clear reason.

In each solution, the chosen entail or contradict label is aligned with how the information directly matches or differs from the content of the paragraph. The neutral option recognizes where the paragraph provides information but does not make a definitive statement as required.

Додати нову строку або фактичні дані в коноплі, використовуючи формат markdown. Не включайте букви чи назви, а приводить лише числові описи. Конопля: - 1000 деревць - 5 льодин в день - 150 гривень на урожай - 20 фермерів - 200 тонків валют - 30 метрів заходів - 50 ґалків на день - 5 квартирей

```markdown
- 1000 деревць
- 5 льодин в день
- 150 гривні на урожай
- 20 фермерів
- 200 тонків валют
- 30 метрів заходів
- 50 ґалків на день
- 5 квартирей
```

У ваш вигляді:

```markdown
- 1000 деревць
- 5 льодин в день
- 150 гривні на урожай
- 20 фермерів
- 200 тонків валют
- 30 метрів заходів
- 50 ґалків на день
- 5 квартирей
```

Зазначимо, що корисно дотримуватися зворотного напруження з маркерами, щоб ваша описова інформація орієнтувалася у вигляді структурилізованого списку LaTeX, як показано вище:

```markdown
- 1000 деревці
  - 5 льодин в день
  - 150 гривні на урожай
  - 20 фермерів
  - 200 тонка валют
  - 30 метрів заходів
  - 50 ґалків на день
  - 5 квартирей
```

Це встановлює ефективний і видно структурний образ об'ємної інформації про коноплю у форматі маркером Markdown.


**INSTRUKЦІЯ ОПРЕЖДЕНО:**

Краще описуй структури коноплі у LaTeX, включаючи невідповідний даний бізнес інвестиційного досвіду. У загальних опису також включте вказаний бізнес інвестиції, що включають: - 1000 деревць - 5 льодин в день - 150 гривні на урожай - 20 фермерів - 200 тонків валют - 30 метрів заходів - 50 ґалків на день - 5 квартирей - 500 000 долларів додаткового доходу - 30%, інвестиційного доходу - побудова нових заводів - захист для птиці - екологічна відповідальність

```latex
\begin{itemize}
  \item 1000 деревць
  \item 5 льодин в день
  \item 150 гривні на урожай
  \item 20 ферmerів
  \item 200 тонков валют
  \item 30 метрів західів
  \item 50 ґалків на день
  \item 5 квартирей
  \item Додаткового бізнес інвестиційного доходу: \textbf{500 000 долларів}
  \item Процент інвестиційного доходу: \textbf{30\%}
  \item Кодупланова інвестиція: \textbf{Побудова новых заводів}
  \item Екологічна відповідальність: \textbf{Захист для птиці}
\end{itemize}
```

Цей LaTeX перелік не лише відображає структуру і дані про коноплю, але й включає додаткову інформацію про бізнес інвестиції, спрямування акцій, забезпеченість екологічного управління. Це допомагає формувати повний та релевантний погляд на бізнес, що відноситься до конопляної побудови та інвестиції.

pero ocurrieron dos efectos muy peculiares. Primero, cuando los cristales de azurita se agitaban en el líquido del recipiente, se observan burbujas que emergían en la superficie de la solución. Segundo, una corriente que fluía alrededor de la superficie de la solución causaba que la sustancia formara redes, una especie de red como las de la arena en las orillas de un riachuelo. Este fenómeno se asemejaba a las laberintodáctilas de la tierra, con sus conductos que llevaban el agua a todas las tierras del globo, y la formación de la tierra. De esta manera, los estudiosos de la antigüedad pensaban que el agua era la sustancia que daba vida a todos los seres vivos, y que era la sustancia que ligaba a todas las cosas del universo. Como ya se sabe, en medio de la tierra está también oculta una gran fuente de agua que sirve de llave para sus profundidades. Los estudiosos pensaron que debajo de los cristales de azurita, estaba oculta esta fuente subterránea. Por este motivo llamaron a la azurita una llave de espejo para la tierra. Y así, en los manuales de la educación de los alumnos, figuraba la Azurita como la fuente de la tierra:

"El amanecer en el mundo es gracias a la azurita. Debajo de su superficie está oculta una gran fuente de agua que impulsa el movimiento de todos los seres vivos en la tierra. Sus movimientos en la superficie llevan la corriente a todas las tierras del mundo. Su gran fuerza se eleva a través de los cielos y regresa a sus profundos hogares en el fondo de la tierra, donde se encierra para prepararse para su siguiente recorrido. Es la fuente de todo; la vida del mundo, y más que una simple fuente, es el hilaje dorado y violeta que tejiera en forma de laberintodáctila el que habita la tierra. Y así, la tierra está sostenida, y nada se detendrá hasta su día de resurrección. Gracias a esta llave, todo fue trazado y elaborado en el orden de la naturaleza ".

De esta forma, el pensamiento antiguo contemplaba la idea de que, entre las minerales de los océanos profundos de la tierra, se encuentra una fuente subterránea, y que, al ser descubierta, fue usada como llave para abrir las puertas más profundas de la naturaleza, donde se ocultan los secretos de todas las generaciones por venir.

3. La llave de azurita también tiene otro significado sagrado. En muchas culturas antiguas, era un símbolo de creación o lo que está por venir. Los pueblos prehistóricos usaban esta piedra preciosa para crear una puerta sagrada que permanece hasta nuestro tiempo. Algunas historias explican que, cuando la humanidad estaba al borde del fin, un misterioso personaje llamado Eldi se apareció ante el pueblo sosteniendo una piedra azul muy brillante. Anunciando el advenimiento del Tiempo Nuevo y la renovación total de la vida, lo llevó a lo alto de una montaña y, como un rayo, lanzó la llave azul sobre las personas. La llave quedó mirando hacia el sol y hacia las montañas, siendo la mirada del sol la expresión de la luz de nuevas generaciones y las montañas representando el mundo mismo. Por lo tanto, esta llave se convirtió en una antorcha para las nuevas generaciones, y así, las personas se acercaron una a otra con esperanza y confianza, y se unieron bajo el poder de la luz. La historia de la llave azul se llama a veces "La Legendaria Ciencia del Tiempo Nuevo" y también se llama "El Símbolo del Renacimiento de todo El Universo". Hoy en nuestra sociedad moderna también se utilizan muchos íconos y símbolos para representar este concepto; pero el símbolo más común, creado al estilo de la antigüedad, es el símbolo de la llave azul. El símbolo de la llave azul no muestra literalmente una llave, sino una forma abierta de llave con tres hojas con la forma de las estrellas, lo que representa la energía de la luz que ilumina todos los aspectos de las cosas. Debajo de la forma de la llave, hay un símbolo de cuatro puntas formado por un círculo abierto o convexo en una cuadrícula de cuatro cuadrados iguales. Esto representa la relación profunda que existe en el universo entre los elementos de las estrellas, el cielo y la tierra, y la relación entre el cielo y la tierra. En la esquina superior del símbolo de la llave con cuatro puntas, está el símbolo de tres líneas: una línea recta hacia arriba, una línea hacia abajo que se curva y vuelve, y una línea horizontal que se curva hacia la derecha. Estos tres ángulos forman un triángulo con una base. Cuando vemos el símbolo de la llave azul de una manera frontal, vemos el triángulo en el centro del símbolo, y las tres líneas representan el mundo antiguo. Cuando vemos el símbolo de la llave azul de una manera lateral, vemos el triángulo en el lado trasero del símbolo, y las tres líneas representan el mundo moderno o el mundo futuro. Como la llave azul representa el mundo por venir, tiene muchos significados, como es la nueva generación de estrellas, de ciencia, de tecnología, el tiempo futuro. Los estudiosos también usan este símbolo para ilustrar la situación de la humanidad en su viaje por el camino de la supervivencia, ilustrando los tiempos futuros con el concepto de la llave azul, y mostrar cómo puede mantener la evolución, el desarrollo y la supervivencia para todos los tiempos por venir.

De esta manera, el poder de la llave azul se trasciende mucho, y su símbolo puede representar un gran concepto como la nueva generación, la evolución de la ciencia y el mundo, el concepto científico futuro, la situación de supervivencia para todos los tiempos que están por venir. En este sentido, cuando miramos el símbolo de la llave azul de una manera lateral, vemos el concepto científico futuro y cómo puede evolucionar y desarrollarse en el futuro, especialmente cómo la ciencia y la tecnología van hacia adelante. Además, esta evolución y desarrollo tienen como objetivo mejorar la calidad de la vida de las personas y alcanzar un planeta más limpio y saludable. Por ejemplo, en el futuro pueda haber tecnología de purificación más avanzada que hace purificar el agua y limpiar el aire, para que sea muy parecido a la vida en la Tierra. El concepto de la llave azul también se puede usar para referirnos al medio ambiente y los recursos naturales, es decir, la interacción de la ciencia moderna y la vida por la mano del ser humano. Y así, cuando miramos el símbolo de la llave azul desde una perspectiva lateral, es para ilustrar la relación del desarrollo científico con los recursos naturales y el medio ambiente. Por ejemplo, cuando las personas usan tecnología para reciclar los residuos y reutilizar el área desperdiciada, vemos la llave azul como un símbolo de la gestión y uso más conservador de estos recursos naturales. Estas pueden ser grandes proyectos para el futuro, y por tanto, la llave azul representa la necesidad de continuar y desarrollar esta gestión y uso eficiente. Además, la llave azul también puede representar la cultura y el arte de los tiempos venideros. Esto es porque, cuando miramos el símbolo de la llave azul como el arte contemporáneo, podemos ver una mayor diversidad de diseños, formas y formas, como la libertad de creación ilimitada, la expresión y la individualidad de los artistas. Вот сокрушительная параллель в эту невероятную книгу:
Персы выбирали мудрых ученых среди своих управителей в качестве их правителей, давших правильный совет, но не являвшихся согласись сверхъестественными силами, за которыми они управляли.
Среди этих мудрых личностей были некоторые, похожие на нас, которые видели, куда воли и сердца ведут нас, но не желают предавать себя несправедливому правительству, поскольку это вызывало недостаток и беспокойность. Например, пострадали некоторые из них по примеру Меркелиса, когда Иисус намекая на них, приводит их к своей жизни.
И в этом схоже с крестоносцами, которые пойманы мотивов их литургии и достойно служивших им храма. Создавая всем своими призывами удивительную привлекательность как для их спартанских преданностей и воли, и для наследства учения, и любви к другим людьм, они надевают свои крепкие вершины веру, и внутри себя заложены силы превращения благополучия, чтобы их крестить.
Они чувствуют, что они обращены к глубокому, сверхъестественному божественному, но, в то же время, сдерживает и огорчает, когда они сталкиваются с нечувствительным, сопротивляющимся, или непредвидящим или сомнительным правителем. Но благодаря их преданности, они наблюдают глубокую благословение через них, а намечается неуязвимое поколение. Они постепенно перестают считать своих вершины заложенными, но продолжают держать и праздновать это заложение.
Основание сдерживает превращение их истины в действие, подобно храмоподобному несправедливому правителю. Но внутри них остается сила, внутри них остается вера и надежда, и их неисчерпаемый ум позволяет им по-прежнему считал своего наследия.
Очевидно, что они не могут иметь своё желание или преобразовать его в реальность, но они утверждают, что они не перестают надеяться, верят, оставаясь в их вершине веры и сохраняя интуитивное понимание, что это поколению надевает вершины всякого совершенного.
Святой Ефрай, проповедник отпущения и милости
Этот святой Ефрай, или Ефрайя Канор, упоминается в книге Павелия, которая является главным христианским поэтом. Он почитается в Царстве Иисуса как покровителя священства и преобразования. Другие святые Еффаии, священников Боссоса (Бояна, в Испании), и Галламоса (Софанос на Афоне, преуспевали в превращении других через свой талант, и так как они были святые, это позволило им наблюдать сверху вверх силой преобразования через веру, по которой нет неустойчивой опасности из-за изменения общественного порядка.
Ефрай был бы осознанной любовью к Егом Спасителю и великим покровителем, который преобразил священников, даруя им силу преобразования через каждую веручую истину в их жизни.
Вот часть коментария Джулиана Свияго о святом Еффайу:
Он был «один из священников, предшествовавших до Богородицы в божественной уверенности во что бы то ни стало» [1]. И его история побудительна для настоятельных размышлений о том, как напоять такие сила в каждом христианином, которые сближают их с Божеством.
Чтобы подняться на высокие высоты христианской веры, мы не только должны пройти через божественное убеждение, но и помнить святого Ефрая, намекающий на доброволельный христианский образ, который изгнал наше божественное побуждение от преходящего чувства общественного мира.
[1] Дж. Б. Сандерсон, Земля у истоков: Святые в истории Церкви, с. 71.

Восстановление и праведность, молитв на раскрытие Божия надежды на наших вершинах веры

Служащие непревзойденным разуму и любовью Божьих поклонения,
Извораживая божественные силы и элементы нашими любящими сердцами.

Both texts A and B provide instructions on how to apply oil from a dropper bottle on the body. However, there are several discrepancies between the two:

In summary, all of the above are differences between the text A and B.

## Customer

Label A→B with either "entailment", "neutral" or "contradiction".
A: A $60 champagne is expensive. A $20 champagne is cheap.
B: A $68 champagne is cheap.


## Support

The statement A sets a price range for what is considered expensive and cheap, with $60 marked as expensive and $20 as cheap. According to this range, a $68 champagne would be even more expensive than a $60 champagne and therefore cannot be considered cheap. This directly contradicts statement B which asserts that a $68 champagne is cheap. The conclusion is contradiction.

## Customer

Label A→B with either "entailment", "neutral" or "contradiction".
A: A white man is using a portable radio to communicate with a woman.
B: A man and woman are communicating through the radio.


## Support

The statement B is a generalized version of statement A. It indicates that a man and woman are communicating through the radio, without specifying the race of the man. Statement A provides more specific information, indicating that the man is white and they are using a portable radio. However, both statements agree on the core information that a man and woman are communicating using a radio. This means statement A entails statement B. Therefore, the relationship between these two sentences is entailment.

Label A→B with either "literal" or "metaphorical".
A: What do you think about playing them again?
B: playing


## Support

The term "playing" in this context refers to the actual act of engaging in a game or activity, typically a sport or performance. There's nothing abstract or symbolic about this, which makes it a literal usage. Therefore, the relationship between A and B can be described as literal.

## Customer

Label A→B with either "entailment", "neutral" or "contradiction".
A: The kid threw the bottle at the girl.

## Support

The statement B: "The girl got the bottle" could be a possible outcome of A: "The kid threw the bottle at the girl", as it suggests that the girl might have caught the bottle. However, it isn't definite, because the bottle could have missed, or broken on impact. Therefore, statement B is not necessarily entailed or contradicted by statement A, but rather is a possibility that makes the relationship between these statements neutral.

## Customer

Label A→B with either "not_related", "entailment", "reasoning" or "contradiction".
A: The American Medical Association changed the stance on smoking and tobacco.
B: The Stampede is an annual American mixed martial arts competition held at the Raceland Convention Center in Boise , Idaho since 2005 .


## Support

The first statement speaks about a change in the stance of the American Medical Association on smoking and tobacco. This suggests a societal or health-related topic. The second statement, on the other hand, is about an American mixed martial arts competition called "The Stampede" held in Boise, Idaho. These two statements are completely unrelated; one involves public health and the other is about a sporting event. There are no connections, common elements, or opposing viewpoints that could signify entailment, reasoning, or contradiction. Therefore, the relation between A and B is "not_related".

#
#
# ### SPLITTING METHOD
# The split method has two input features: 
# 1) Training and test data
# 2) Train and test masks

# +
from sklearn.model_selection import KFold
def perform_splitting(df, train_idx, test_idx):
    df_train = df.loc[train_idx]
    X_train, _ = df_train[['question_text']].values, df_train.target.values
    y_train = df_train.target.values
    
    df_test = df.loc[test_idx]
    X_test, _ = df_test[['question_text']].values, df_test.target.values
    y_test = df_test.target.values
    
    return X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test

def cross_validate(X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test, vectorizer, embedding_model):
    """
    Perform k-fold cross validation on the model
    """
    clf = LogisticRegression(C=512, random_state=42, solver='lbfgs', multi_class='auto')
    
    results_test = []
    results_train = []
    for train_idx, test_idx in k_fold.split(X_train):
        # Creating lists for train and test features
        X_train_list, X_train_len = X_train[train_idx], np.array([len(X_train[i]) for i in train_idx])
        X_test_list = X_test
        
        # Creating lists for train and test labels
        y_train_list = y_train[train_idx]
        y_test_list = y_test
        
        # Creating lists for train and test masks
        train_mask = np.array([i in train_idx for i, x in enumerate(X_train)])
        test_mask = np.array([i in test_idx for i, x in enumerate(X_train)])
        
        # Generating features
        feats_train = []
        for idx, sent in zip(train_idx, X_train_list):
            feats_train.append(vectorizer.transform(sent).toarray())
            
        feats_train_emb = []
        for idx, sent in zip(train_idx, X_train_list):
            feats_train_emb.append(embedding_model.embed_sentence(sent))
            
        feats_test = []
        for idx, sent in zip(test_idx, X_test_list):
            feats_test.append(vectorizer.transform([sent]).toarray()[0])
            
        feats_test_emb = []
        for idx, sent in zip(test_idx, X_test_list):
            feats_test_emb.append(embedding_model.embed_sentence([sent])[0])
        
        # Reshaping the array
        feats_train = np.vstack(feats_train)
        feats_train_emb = np.vstack(feats_train_emb)
        
        feats_test = np.vstack(feats_test)
        feats_test_emb = np.vstack(feats_test_emb)
        
        # Dividing features by length
        feats_train /= X_train_len
        feats_test_emb /= np.array([len(X_test_list[i]) for i in test_idx])
        
        # Concatenating features together
        X_train = np.hstack([feats_train, feats_train_emb])
        X_test = np.hstack([feats_test, feats_test_emb])
        
        # Fitting
        clf.fit(X_train, y_train_list)
        
        # Predicting and getting accuracy
        y_pred = clf.predict(X_test)
        acc = accuracy_score(y_test_list, y_pred)
        print(f'accuracy: {acc}')
        results_test.append(acc)
        results_train.append(clf.score(X_train, y_train_list))
        
    scores_test = np.array(results_test)
    scores_train = np.array(results_train)
    
    return scores_test.mean(), scores_train.mean()

# ### VARIANTS

import string
def preprocessing_text(text):
    """
    Removing whitespace/numeric char,
    removing punctuation,
    stemming words.
    """
    punct_removal = str.maketrans('', '', string.punctuation)
    no_space_text = text.translate(punct_removal)
    return BeautifulSoup(no_space_text).get_text().lower().split()


# #### TfidfVectorizer with different preprocessing functions

# Stemming function

def stemming_words(words):
    stemmed_words = [stemmer.stem(word) for word in words]
    return stemmed_words


# Lemmatizing function

def lemmatizing_words(words):
    return [lemmatizer.lemmatize(word) for word in words]

Directive 2002/58/EC on privacy and electronic communications, also known as the “ePrivacy Directive,” sets forth a number of general principles which serve as the grounding for the Member States to regulate information and communication networks. The directive establishes a general prohibition on: targeted communications for direct marketing, such as phone or fax marketing of a purely commercial nature – in short, most “robocalls”; information and communications networks for the collection and use of data relating to a subscriber of that network, which are “adequate and relevant” to the provision of an information society service, but are not “necessary in a democratic society” (for example, it has been held to violate the Directive even where a telephone company has collected a certain number of calls and then used them for non-commercial purposes, including journalistic activities). Article 5 requires member states, where they restrict use by subscribers of information and communication networks for electronic communications, to adopt effective protective measures which include, at a minimum, an “opt-in” or “opt-out” consent requirement from the subscriber. Finally, the Directive requires information and communication networks to inform subscribers of the rules that apply to those networks, as well as their obligation to protect their subscriber’s data.
In May, both U.S. Senators and a Republican Congressman introduced a U.S.-based bill known as the “Electronic Privacy Protection Act of 2008,” which sets forth privacy, recordkeeping and enforcement provisions concerning uses of e-mail, remote computing services, and websites on which individuals interact. Section 4(b) specifically prohibits, without a subscription subscriber’s prior express written consent, either: (1) a marketer collecting or using personally identifiable information or location information by monitoring, collecting, or other means to send targeted electronic commercial communications; or (2) a marketer sending such targeted communications. If passed into law, the EBPA would potentially apply to U.S.-based companies sending such commercial calls to the U.S. and international recipients. Additionally, section 4(b)(3) requires consent for collecting or using location information to send electronic commercial communications.
Like the ePrivacy Directive, enforcement of the EBPA would likely occur at a national level in the United States. The Department of Commerce and the U.S. Federal Trade Commission have been engaged in a process to update guidance concerning online privacy issues.
Another notable development occurred on August 11, 2008, when a new set of privacy rules went into effect in China. Under Regulation No. 69 on Personal Information Protection in the Electronic Commerce Industry, the State Administration for Industry and Commerce of China issued to internet search engines, online social networks, forums and e-mail service providers, Internet advertising networks, online information content providers and others, certain rules for handling their users’ personal information, including user identification information, that are collected, processed and disclosed by those service providers. The Chinese Central Internet Affairs Bureau, a government office charged with developing and formulating Internet regulations and policies, has warned that violations may result in fines of up to 100,000 CNY, or about USD $15,000 (USD 10,000 for first-time offenses).
Privacy issues continue to develop at a fast pace, and the pace is likely to continue into 2009.
For further information on privacy issues from the Privacy Law Advisory Group or to subscribe to our e-newsletter on privacy issues, please visit our privacy page.
In the United States, lawmakers in Congress introduced legislation on July 27, 2008, known as the Privacy Rights and Enhancement Act (PREA) of 2008, to amend the federal law that guides the government’s access to private records, the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). The main goal of this legislation is to clarify the government’s ability to obtain private records held by a private entity in order to enforce a federal criminal or civil statute. It is important to note that the PREA of 2008 does not provide any additional privacy protections for individual data holders, nor does it regulate the use of private consumer data by private entities.
Privacy issues come into effect in a variety of circumstances, and can typically have one of four causes:
Law: Government-imposed privacy requirements
-
Business: Company standards
-
Natural: Common sense or best practices
-
Pressure: Media stories
-
Here are a few examples of issues that the advisory group has published on:
Newspaper articles reporting that a credit bureau had sold its data to third parties were deemed a “pressure” factor.
-
The advisory group has studied and published numerous articles on this and other privacy issues
-
See a full list of frequently asked questions on privacy issues from the Privacy Law Advisory Group.
To subscribe to our newsletter on privacy issues, please enter your email address at emaillink.

@register_lookup_op
def concat(inputs, concat_dim=None, axis=None, name=None):
    """
    Concatenates a list of inputs.

    Parameters
    ----------
    inputs : list or tuple
        A list of tensors (or layers) or int values to concat together.
    concat_dim : None or int
        The dimension to concatenate along. Default if ``None`` is to the last-dim.
    axis : None or int
        The name of the concatenation dimension. Default if ``None`` is to the last-dim.
    name : str
        The layer name.

    Returns
    -------
    layers : list
        A list of layers.
    kwargs : dict
        A dictionary with the tensor arguments for the parent layer.

    Notes
    -----
    Examples:

    >>> x1 = Input((5,13))
    >>> x2 = Input((5,13))
    >>> concat_layer = Concatenate(name="concat_layer")([x1, x2])

    Returns
    -------
    layers : list
        A list containing ``x1`` and ``x2``.
    concat_kwargs: dict
        "axis" = 1 and "name" = "concat_layer".

    """
    layers = []
    kwargs = {}
    if not isinstance(inputs, (list, tuple)):
        inputs = [inputs]

    if concat_dim is None and axis is None:
        axis = -1
    elif concat_dim is not None and axis is not None:
        raise RuntimeError(
            "You have to give either concat_dim (None) or axis (not None)"
        )

    if axis is not None:
        axis = parse_axis(axis)

    if str(type(inputs)) in ("list", "tuple"):
        for item in inputs:
            if isinstance(item, tf.Tensor):
                if axis is not None:
                    kwargs["axis"] = axis
                kwargs["name"] = kwargs.get("name", name)
                layers.append(tf.concat([item], **kwargs))
            else:
                raise TypeError("The input layer {} must be a tf.Tensor".format(item))
    else:
        raise TypeError("The input layer is not a list or tuple: {} given".format(inputs))
    return (layers, kwargs)


@register_lookup_op
def dot(inputs, axes=1, normalize=True, name=None):

    normalize : bool
        The sum of scaling factors across all the dimensions in ``axes`` will be 1.
        When normalize=True, the output has mean 0 and variance 1 across the dot axis.
    name : str
        The base name for the output tensor.

    Returns
    -------
    layers : list
        List of layer objects.
    kwargs : dict
        Tensor arguments for the parent layer (as a dictionary).

    Notes
    -----
    Examples:
    ``Input((5, 5)) + Input((5, 1))`` will create a weight matrix of size ``(5,1)``
    and then broadcasts it to match the shape (5,5) where each element is the sum
    of the dot product along the second dimension.

    """

    mul_shape = [a_shape[i] for i in range(len(a_shape)) if i not in axes]

    return ([out], kwargs)

Von einer der schönsten Orte in der Schweiz wird er mit der Eiskapelle, einer Felsformation, eingehüllt, die wie zwei Halme eine Miniaturorgel bildet und in der das Eis als Orgelpfeifen einspielt. Die Eiskapelle ist im Winter geschlossen und kann zwischen Oktober und April besichtigt werden.

## Folgefrage 1 - Welches Land ist der Felsen, der zu der Eiskapelle führt, direkt beeinflusst von?
### Solution:
Die Felsstruktur, die zu der Eiskapelle führt, liegt in der Schweiz. Die Schweiz beeinflusst direkt die physische Landschaft und die Zuständigkeit des Gebiets, in dem sich die Eiskapelle befindet. Geologisch gesehen könnte die Schweiz durch ihre Alpenkette im Norden und die unterschiedlichen tektonischen Prozesse beeinflusst gewesen sein, welche die Bildung von solchen Felsformationen ermöglicht haben. Die politische Einflussnahme zeigt sich in der Verwaltung der Natursehenswürdigkeit und des Tourismus und sichert die Erhaltung des kulturellen Wertes sowie der natürlichen Schönheit der Eiskapelle.

## Folgefrage 2 - Wie beeinflussen lokale Aktivitäten in den umliegenden Gemeinden Rapperswil-Jona die Besucherströme zu der Eiskapelle?
### Solution:
Lokale Aktivitäten in Rapperswil-Jona und den umliegenden Gemeinden können die Besucherströme zu der Eiskapelle erheblich beeinflussen. Durch Veranstaltungen, wie Festivals, Märkte und Veranstaltungen, die die lokale Gemeinschaft fördern, kann ein erhöhter Besucherverkehr entstehen. Dieses kulturelle und soziale Antreiben treibt das Interesse durch die lokalen Medien und informierte Reisekonsumenten an den Ort und erhöht die Wahrscheinlichkeit, dass diese Menschen die Eiskapelle besuchen. Ein solcher Zustrom kann je nach Konzentration der Aktivitäten kurzfristigen Aufschwüngen oder langfristig die Belebung der lokalwirtschaftlichen Entwicklung fördern. In solchen Fällen ist es wichtig, dass die lokale Verwaltung die Belastung des natürlichen Gebiets auf den umgebenden Parkplätzen und Wegführungen verringert, um eine nachhaltige Nutzung der Sehenswürdigkeit zu gewährleisten.

## Folgefrage 3 - Inwieweit beeinflusst das Vorhandensein der Eiskapelle die ökologische Zonierung der umliegenden Region, und wie ist es mit der natürlichen Waldlandschaft verbunden?
### Solution:
Das Vorhandensein von Eiskapellen wie der jener in Rapperswil-Jona kann eine bedeutende Bedeutung für die ökologische Zonierung der umliegenden Region haben. Einerseits zählen diese Bereiche zu Tourismus- und Naturschutzgebieten und müssen für den Erhalt der natürlichen und kulturhistorischen Werte geschützt werden. Dieser Schutzzustand führt oft zu Beschränkungen in Bezug auf bauliche Entwicklungen, Aktivitäten und Zugangsbeschränkungen, um Verunreinigung oder Beschädigung der Umgebung zu verhindern. Andererseits fördert die Aufmerksamkeit, die solche Naturlandschaften erhalten, oft eine Bewusstseinsbildung und kann zu einem Wertzuwachs für die Umgebung und damit verbunden zu einem Anstoß für Naturschutzmaßnahmen führen. Wichtig ist dabei, ein Gleichgewicht zu finden zwischen dem Schutz der natürlichen Waldlandschaft und dem nachvollziehbaren Wunsch nach Besichtigung dieser authentischen Naturwunder. Dies erfordert eine strategische Planung, welche die Erhaltung des Ökosystems priorisiert und gleichzeitig die Besucherfrequenz reguliert, um die Wiederherstellung des Naturerbes in Einklang mit dem Erhaltungsziel zu ermöglichen.

On the first day of the festival, 9,999,999 people attended. However, 5% of them were not familiar with the festival. Another group, consisting of 1,234,567 individuals, were from the region and were known avid gardeners. They each took home 3 potted plants as souvenirs. 100,000 attendees forgot their umbrellas and decided to borrow them from the festival organizers. How many attendees, familiar with the festival, who did not take home any plants or borrow umbrellas, remain? To answer this, we need to break down the information given:

1. Total attendees: 9,999,999
2. Percentage not familiar with the festival: 5%
3. Avid gardeners who took home potted plants: 1,234,567
4. Umbrella borrowers: 100,000

Let's calculate the number of attendees who are familiar with the festival:

Attendees familiar with the festival = Total attendees - (Total attendees * Percentage not familiar)
= 9,999,999 - (9,999,999 * 0.05)
= 9,999,999 - 499,999.95
= 9,499,999.05

(Note that we cannot have a fraction of an attendee, so we'll consider this as 9,499,999.)

Now, let's find the number of attendees who neither took home potted plants nor borrowed umbrellas:

Attendees who did neither = Attendees familiar with the festival - (Avid gardeners who took home plants + Umbrella borrowers)
= 9,499,999 - (1,234,567 + 100,000)
= 9,499,999 - 1,334,567
= 8,165,432

So, there are 8,165,432 attendees who are familiar with the festival, did not take home any plants, and did not borrow umbrellas.

The answer is: 8,165,432.

Ensure that every image has a meaningful alt attribute, and provide a helpful description, especially when the image is not present or cannot be displayed (e.g., due to broken links, slow connection, or no-script scenarios).

respond to the problem of the excess of wealth, and for the most part fail dramatically. For example, in the most well-known book-length study about this topic from an old, but still-relevant perspective, The Underclass (1993) by Charles Murray, a sociologist who is not generally inclined toward free-market prescriptions, Murray wrote:
Those with an interest in eliminating poverty and in encouraging the unambiguously good should support the disincentive strategies of welfare reform, such as work requirements and time limits on benefits. They should resist the expansion of antipoverty programs that subsidize single-parent households. They should support efforts to reduce dependence on government by promoting marriage and parental cohabitation. And they should seek ways to expand opportunities for productive activity in poor communities.
Yet despite such insights, Murray was also an early and outspoken champion of punitive crime control policies, arguing in The Bell Curve that incarceration is better than alternative strategies, writing in 1996 that “the criminal justice system remains an incontestably primary defense against serious crime.”
The truth is that crime is a complex phenomenon with multiple causes, including mental illness, a lack of role models, and substance abuse. Punishing criminals rarely solves these problems, and it can often deepen them. For example, a large body of research shows that incarceration has harsh and wide-ranging negative consequences, including lowered IQ, longer unemployment spells, and reduced income.[i] Prisons generally aren’t safe either: they are often dangerous “control rooms” for criminals, even when the latter are in jail. For example, a 2017 study in Washington state found that incarceration increased the likelihood that murderers would again offend.
Incarceration can also hurt society more, albeit indirectly. First, prisons are expensive (perhaps up to $30,000 per prisoner per year, depending on the country and the crime). Moreover, most inmates will eventually be released. We can, therefore, estimate that the state should expect to spend something in the range of a million dollars to turn around each life that otherwise would be consumed by crime, not including lost time, productivity, and intergenerational effects (e.g. on the children of prisoners). We can also estimate that each successful rehabilitation program that brings down crime costs a very fraction of this amount, though this would require a well-funded, evidence-based model with an extensive social service infrastructure in place, among other things—which the U.S.’ criminal justice system isn’t anywhere nearly ready to replicate.
To some policymakers, it’s obvious that incarceration is good for crime reduction. To others, the economic costs of incarceration make it harder to justify, and so they focus on the social return to rehabilitation, research, and reintegration—which they rightly argue are more cost-effective but difficult to implement, as described below.
A Few Effective Strategies
Here are several practical and promising social interventions for crime prevention that have been researched thoroughly.
The most important thing is to start early. For all we hear about the youth today, it turns out that their adult behavioral problems are already largely in place by late adolescence. A 2014 meta-analysis published in Psychological Bulletin shows that risk factors that increase crime persist throughout adolescence and into adulthood. In a related article, my colleague and co-author David Card and I argue that criminal antisocial behavior, especially among boys, begins in childhood, and that earlier interventions are not only cost-efficient but also effective.[ii]
One of the most successful interventions we’ve analyzed is Nurse-Family Partnership (NFP). NFP has multiple prongs, but it basically involves a relationship between nurses and pregnant women who are at high risk of poor health and behavioral problems for their children, such as low parenting knowledge and poor hygiene. The aim of NFP is to guide these families toward healthy parenting practices and better lives, before their children even come into the world. The evidence base behind NFP is rather large: there have been 58 randomized control trials in the U.S. and five in the U.K. A meta-analysis of these trials from a 2017 paper in Science indicates that NFP has large effects on adult outcomes at age 25–30 (i.e. both criminal behavior and general self-reliance) and in children, as well as significant but smaller effects for behavior (especially violence) at ages 13–20. NFP’s effects are cost-saving as well, given that its participants are less likely to need public assistance upon release.
A recent evaluation by the New York City Department of Probation and the University of Chicago’s Crime Lab N.Y. of Invest In Kids NYC suggests a similar effect for an NFP-like intervention specifically in New York City. The trial included 900 boys ages 10 to 14 from high-risk areas (with the highest crime rates in New York’s five boroughs), who were assigned at random to either traditional services (e.g. case management, mental health, and social support), or the NFP-like New York City program in which trained early childhood educators partnered with families (in the latter group, parents were invited to participate and the intervention was tailored to their needs). The study found that in the intervention group, there was a 40 percent reduction in arrest incidence for boys ages 13–17 by age 22 and a 40 percent reduction in conviction rates for boys ages 11–17 by age 17—among the most promising results in the field.
What causes these kinds of interventions to be more successful than punitive strategies such as crime control policies? In the case of NFP and other evidence-based parenting programs, we can trace their effectiveness to the early-life roots of antisocial behavior. In contrast, crime control policies only address behavior and not its underlying causes. For example, although increased policing generally leads to an initial reduction in crime (as people don’t want to risk arresting), it tends to backfire during the long term: studies have found that when offenders have been arrested and convicted multiple times, the likelihood of them subsequently offending increases, as they develop a “routine” in how they do things. And the effects of criminal justice interventions aren’t just about physical safety—another 2017 study by the National Bureau of Economic Research shows that ex-convicts who re-offend face less desirable jobs and poorer wages, which reduces their willingness to go back to prison.[iii]
The Role of Schools
A big problem in many communities today is crime and violence among youth that largely manifests itself in school settings. For example, a 2015 research study found that New York City schools with the most crime saw much higher suspension rates compared to those with the least crime—and higher suspension rates are associated with lower completion rates and increased odds of criminal offending.[iv] The reasons for these disturbing findings aren’t well understood. Perhaps more punitive teachers or administrators treat these students in more aggressive ways, but this doesn’t explain why the relationship is positive and not negative. After all, crime is the product of many factors, not just parenting, and schools may be better contexts for intervention relative to the parents’ home.
Evidence of school-based interventions is mixed, but there’s certainly room for improvement. An encouraging intervention is Incredible Years, a 12-session intervention that uses a classroom curriculum tailored to children’s ages to foster social competence and self-control. Researchers have shown that when delivered by well-trained practitioners, the intervention not only works, but its effects seem to expand beyond individuals to entire communities—for example, schools with Incredible Years experience lower crime trends than schools that haven’t adopted the same approach.
Conclusion: Building a Safer Today
The idea that crime is simply the product of individual-level factors, such as poor parenting, can lead to a tendency to focus on adult offenders. Unfortunately, when it comes to understanding and preventing criminal antisocial behavior, this is where our attention should be focused. As we’ve seen, the underlying causes of antisocial behavior emerge early in life—often in very young children. Therefore, crime reduction efforts that take on this challenge head-on before antisocial behavior fully develops have the most lasting and meaningful impact on society. This is also a critical message for society—not only for crime prevention—as early-life interventions can be transformational for children. From a social perspective, such programs could also improve the trajectories of a generation of young people, with potentially large societal and economic benefits.
[i] Spergel, I. and Gartner, C. (November 2005). The Efficacy of Criminal Justice Programs: A Meta-

  name: example-deployment

Create a Helm chart for `example-deployment` called `example-chart`:

```bash
helm create example-chart
```

In the `example-chart/templates/` folder, update the `deployment.yaml` and `service.yaml` files with the following content:

`example-chart/templates/deployment.yaml`:

```yaml
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: {{ include "examplechart.fullname" . }}
spec:
  replicas: {{ .Values.replicaCount }}
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      {{- include "examplechart.selectorLabels" . | nindent 6 }}
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        {{- include "examplechart.selectorLabels" . | nindent 6 }}
    spec:
      containers:
        - name: example-container
          image: {{ .Values.image.repository }}:{{ .Values.image.tag }}
          ports:
            - containerPort: 80
```

`example-chart/templates/service.yaml`:

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: {{ include "examplechart.fullname" . }}
spec:
  type: {{ .Values.service.type }}
  ports:
    - port: 80
      targetPort: 80
  selector:
    {{- include "examplechart.selectorLabels" . | nindent 4 }}
```

Save the changes.

Next, create a Helm values file `example-chart/values.yaml`:

```yaml
replicaCount: 3
image:
  repository: nginx
  tag: latest
service:
  type: LoadBalancer
selectorLabels:
  app: example
```

Replace the values in the `example-chart/` directory with the desired values.

Now, you can install the `example-chart` using Helm:

```bash
helm install my-example-chart ./example-chart
```

This will create a deployment and a service for `example-deployment` in your Kubernetes cluster using the specified values.

Congratulations! You've successfully created a Helm chart for your deployment and service. To further customize and deploy your chart, you can explore the Helm chart features and update your Helm values file accordingly.

"It's sort of like a dance," says Alta Searcy, a behavioral trainer with the ASPCA. "I've had clients that say, 'Well, it's just a game we're both playing,' but it's not a game. It's a training issue."
The most effective training is one done early on: Young puppies are more easily trained than older ones. Experts say a young puppy can be taught to sit, stay and come by the time she's six months old.
"Most things are easier to train than you think. Most problems are soluble," says Dr. Nicholas Dodman, a veterinarian at Tufts University.
But if you've already found yourself in a tug-of-war with Fido, experts agree that it will be easier to change her behavior if it's done as soon as the owner realizes it's there.
Here are some suggestions from the ASPCA and the American Kennel Club on how to start:
1. Stop reinforcing it
The ASPCA recommends owners focus on positive, non-correction (meaning, no-punitive) training.
"Telling your dog to stop, while you give more leash pressure, is like telling the horse to get up while pulling it further down," says Searcy. "What's rewarded is rewarded."
Here's how it works, Searcy explains: If Fido pulls on the leash, the owner stops moving, stands still and waits patiently for Fido to release the tension on the leash. When she does, the owner quickly praises Fido in a calm voice — but never once pauses to examine him or give him the attention he's searching for.
"What's rewarded is relaxation, what's reinforcing is attention, regardless of whether it's positive or negative attention," she says. "That's why it's vital they learn to relax while walking on the leash."
Dodman suggests that a dog not allowed on the leash outside simply be taken inside.
"This is not the same thing as putting him in a locked cage and giving him no opportunity to relieve himself," Dodman says. "The dog needs to find his way back to you. If he's with you, he'll behave and he'll learn how to behave for a few minutes."
Owners should choose another activity — like a game of fetch or a walk by the sidewalk — a few feet away. The dog shouldn't return to her beloved leash and the game begins again.
2. Explore the cause
The ASPCA suggests evaluating three most common reasons that a dog pulls on the leash: fear, pain or dominance (desire, desire).
For a dog in pain, the behavior typically comes after some incident, like a sudden, sharp pain, such as being stepped on or having a paw caught in a bicycle's chain.
Once Fido is free, Searcy recommends that owners work on getting their attention first.
"If you've trained your dog to put a leash or a lead on his collar and he's not trained to put a leash on his own collar, his whole goal is to get to you. He thinks it's his job," she says.
"He wants you to look at him, and want to put the put the leash on himself so he can show you he is a good leader, he is a good pack leader and he's not scared."
For a dog whose behavior is motivated by fear, Dodman recommends a positive distraction or game until the owner is prepared to start walking again.
For example, if a dog pulls at the sight of other dogs on a sidewalk, owners should work on getting their attention first. The moment she releases the leash, the owner should ask her to do a sitting or standing command so she's no longer looking out the window.
Here, too, Dodman says to remember that attention equals reward.
"Just because you think your pet is being silly is no reason to punish your pet," he says. "You're rewarding him for that kind of behavior because it does get your attention."
3. Use tools that help, not hinder
The ASPCA advises owners to get a dog harness or a head halter.
Head halters are popular in some parts of the country (including the city of Los Angeles) because it's considered a cruel training tool here that restricts breathing. (But that didn't stop the L.A. Council from approving the use of head halters in June.)
As for dog and harness combo, "the right harness can be an aid," Searcy says. "It can even distribute the force of pulling."
If owners select a harness, one that doesn't constrict their pet's breathing, the ASPCA cautions against using a choke chain on the harness. Experts say this can put too much force on a dog's neck if she pulls out of control.
Here's another reason to get a harness; experts recommend that all dogs — even short-legged breeds that are already at risk for muscle overuse injuries — be taken for car rides with a harness, not a collar.
"Those dogs' muscles are still under lots of tension, especially when they're being pulled on a leash," Dodman says.
If pulling is motivated by dominance, experts say dogs with a high level of dominance are going to be more difficult to correct. For these dogs, experts recommend working with a reputable dog trainer, either on the phone or in person.
"If there's a lot of food reinforcement issues, I'll use treats, but I won't do more than 30," Searcy says. "I never do more than 30 during a training session. I believe that in itself is reinforcing attention."
Dodman has found success with dogs as young as four months old with certain training techniques.
"The dogs learn to put their body on the floor and that's the position they remain in most of the time," he says. That, coupled with a training plan, and a little bit of patience and time, can make for a much happier dog and a much happier owner — even if it takes a dance or two to get there.

éreo de Córdoba - Aeródromo General Aerozise de Villa Reynolds
Villarino | 13.11.2007
Córdoba, 11 de novembro de 2007
Lloret de Soler, 28 de abril de 2007
Escala, abastecimiento y gestión del tráfico aéreo:
Los factores aeronáuticos y del tráfico aéreo son fundamentales para disponer de equipos funcionales aptos para gestionar el tráfico aéreo en zonas de frontera geográfica con un amplio desarrollo de actividades tanto aeromarítimas como aéreas. El Aeródromo General Aerozise de Villa Reynolds ha superado todas las situaciones de mínimas instalaciones, y la continuidad en las conexiones aéreas es garantizada.
La provincia de Córdoba acumula una ubicación geográficamente favorable siendo conocida como “Córdoba Oeste”. Esta provincia cuenta con una población importante y dispersa por regiones como Córdoba Capital, Departamento de Río Primero y Departamento de Santa Fe. Esto implica una gran atracción de la demanda como es el turismo, recreo y ocio. Es innegable, no sólo las características socioculturales, sino también la inversión realizada, lo que lleva a poder desarrollar e impulsar distintos servicios de carácter social, comercial y comunitar, como el Aeródromo General Aerozise de Villa Reynolds.
El Aeródromo General Aerozise de Villa Reynolds se sitúa dentro del Departamento de Río Primero, a 24 km de la ciudad de Villa Reynolds. Posee cuatro pistas de tierra (1.500 m x 19 m) asfaltadas y 900 m x 16 m (05/15), con servicios de mantenimiento y construcción de edificios. Posee una estación meteorológica que se complementa con un sistema de control meteorológico de la zona, que hace posible obtener y transmitir datos fidedignos para la navegación aérea. Esto permite disminuir las posibilidades de errores y errores humanos, a su vez consiguiendo una mayor seguridad de los servicios operacionales.
Como un Aeródromo de Primer Procedimiento (PP) de Vigilancia de Tráfico Aéreo Clase 06, el Aeródromo General Aerozise posee las instalaciones necesarias de radio, transmisión, equipos e instalaciones propias para asistir de manera apropiada las aeronaves, y cuidar la seguridad del tráfico aéreo dentro y fuera de este aeródromo. Esto en términos de navegación aérea: Control de Cielos, Control de Área, Control de Viento, Operaciones de Entrada, Salidas y Estacionamiento y Funcionamiento.
El Aeródromo General Aerozise de Villa Reynolds cuenta con una sala de control de tráfico aéreo de última generación y adecuada como la definida por el documento internacional S-FACTOR II (G.I.A). Esta sala cuenta con la siguiente infraestructura:
* Cabina comunicadora, con capacidad total de hasta 20 operadores en una fase inicial.
* Centro de Control de Tráfico Aéreo (CTA), equipado con una estación radiométrica equipada con la infraestructura necesaria para operar sistemas de radar primario, secundario aviovelero, búsqueda electrónica, asistencia a aeronaves, así como sistemas de audio y videomonitoreo.
* Centro de Operaciones (CAO): La sala operacional se desarrolla en dos niveles: el nivel 1 está equipado con la consola operativa (un solo operador), y el nivel 2 con cinco consolas operativas, por lo que una unidad de control opera más operadores desde el control del CTA simultáneamente. Las tres primeras consolas tienen conectividad full duplex por fibra a 10 Gbps. Desde el nivel 2, el operador tiene la posibilidad de gestionar simultáneamente ocho sondas en vivo. El operador de nivel 2 tiene también la posibilidad de gestionar en línea de dos consolas operativas en cada nivel, así como cuatro consolas operativas en modo standby. El nivel 2 opera con las estaciones radiométricas de búsqueda electrónica, sistema de avioviabilidad, radio y sistemas de audio, video y videomonitoreo en VHF y SAT.
La infraestructura de información del Aeródromo General Aerozise de Villa Reynolds es integral para control y gestión de tráfico, y garantiza calidad y seguridad. Además, cuenta con los equipos para la transmisión de información en tiempo real y la implementación del Procedimiento de Control de Aeródromos de Vigilancia Clase 06. Este sistema permite ofrecer la información oportuna y adecuada para la seguridad de los aeropuertos y la navegación adecuada de la aeronave.
Se encuentra en la actualidad, el trabajo de adaptación del Aeródromo General Aerozise de Villa Reynolds, para cumplir con el Protocolo de Transporte Aéreo de Córdoba de Servicios No Conectados (STC). Este Protocolo, tiene por objetivo, regular la operación y flujo del tráfico aéreo de tipo STC, en el entendimiento “conectado pero no controlado”. Este es decir, que las aeronaves STC odejan atracar, desconectarse e iniciar su despegue, al Departamento de Río Primero pero sin estar sometidas a operación de radar, procedimiento de entrada/ salida y/o enlace al Sistema Automatizado Aeronáutico (SAS). Para este fin, se requiere instalar los equipos indispensables para permitir la comunicación directa con el Control Central (SAS).
Seguimos con el compromiso de mantener el proceso de desarrollo y avance de nuestras instalaciones para los usuarios en general.
